Fierro b Institute of Catalysis, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, 1113 Sofia, Bulgaria b lnstituto de Catalysis y Petroleoquimica, C.S.LC., Campus UAM, Cantoblanco, 28049 Madrid, Spain Received 18 July 1995; revised 25 February 1996; accepted 28 February 1996 Abstract Titania-supported 12-molybdophosphoric acid and its Co(Ni) salts were studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and Fourier transform IR spectroscopy in the mid-infrared range and of adsorbed nitric oxide and pyridine. Hydrodesulphurization of thiophene was used as test reaction of the samples. The results provide additional support for the preservation of phosphoro- molybdate anion on titania-support after its supporting. The highest activity of nickel promoted catalysts may be caused by an increase in dispersion of molybdenum and its lighter reduction. Keywords: 12-Molybdophosphoric acid; Anatase: FTIR; XPS; Hydrodesulphurization catalysts 1. Introduction In recent years, the investigations devoted to the study of heteropoly com- pounds increased. The attraction of these compounds is provoked by the presence of anions of the Keggin type structure [1,2]. Studies of the catalytic behaviour of heteropoly compounds have concentrated on unsupported acids and salts. Although the supported system seems to be more interesting from a practical point of view, relatively few studies of supported catalysts have been reported. Carbon [3,4] and silica [5-10] as supports have usually been used for obtaining high surface area catalysts with supported heteropoly compounds which are effective catalysts for oxidation * Corresponding author. 0926-860X/96/$15.00 Copyright 1996 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. PII S0926- 860X(96)001 04-4 60 S. Damyanoca, J.L. G. Fierro / Applied Catalysis A: General 144 (1996) 59-77 processes. The stability of silica-supported 12-molybdophosphoric and 12- molybdosilic acids up to 843 K as catalysts for methane oxidation have been shown by Moffat et al. [5]. However, with some supports (such as alumina) there is a problem concerning the stability of basic centres on their surfaces that leads to the decomposition of polyanions. Rao et al. [6] have questioned the stability of HPMo supported on alumina and silica-alumina on the basis of NMR investigation, In contrast, Cheng and Luthra [7] studying HPMo on alumina by the same technique, concluded that the decomposition of polyanions occurs as a result of an interaction between the support and HPA which leads to the formation of an aluminium salt. According to Fricke and Ohlman [8,9], the thermal stability of heteropolyanions decreases when supported on silica; the lower the concentration on the support, the lower the stability. Rocchiccioli-De- ltcheff et al. [10] suggested that the Keggin unit destruction occurs at lower temperatures for silica-supported HPMo than for the unsupported one. The studies of the catalytic and surface properties of heteropoly catalysts in oxidation processes have been related to the acid and salts containing monova- lent cations [11,12], while significantly fewer investigations of salts with multivalent cations have appeared [ 13-15]. We have attempted to demonstrate [16] that titania-supported 12- molybdophosphoric, 12-molybdosilic and 12-molybdotitanic heteropoly acids are precursors of active phase in hydrodesulphurization catalysts. The present paper is a continuation of the study of titania-supported 12-molybdophosphoric acid and its Co and Ni salts as catalysts for hydrodesulphurization [17]. The aim of the work is to obtain additional information on the location of the molybde- num and promoter atoms on titania support. In order to obtain information on the surface properties of the catalysts in their oxidized and reduced states IR and XPS techniques were used. The degree of involving of the effect of the counterion on the surface and catalytic properties of the samples in the reaction of thiophene hydrodesulphurization is investigated. 2. Experimental 2.1. Catalyst preparation All catalysts were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method using anatase (SBET = 100 m2/g) as a support. The titania-supported 12- molybdophosphoric acid samples (HPMo/T) and its Co and Ni salts were prepared by impregnation of the support with aqueous solutions of purified HPMo and its corresponding salts, respectively. The salts were prepared from an aqueous reaction of the parent acid, to which the required stoichiometric quantity of counter cation salts was added, as described by Tsigdinos [14]. The S. The content of molybdenum varied in the range 5.4-12.9 wt.-% and 0.5-1.0 wt.-% for Co and Ni (Table 1). The supported salts with stoichiometric substituted H+ ion by Co2+ and Ni2+ cations are abbreviated as CoPMo/T and NiPMo/T, respectively. The series of samples with various metal loadings will be noted by indexes 1 and 2 for higher and lower molybdenum-containing catalyst, respectively. 2.2. Infrared measurements Infrared spectra in the range 1200-600 cm-1 were obtained by pressing wafers of the sample mixed with KBr in proportion 1:100. For FT-IR studies of adsorbed nitric oxide, the oxide catalysts were pressed in self-supporting discs and pre-treated by evacuating at 623 K for 1 h within a portable infrared cell equipped with greaseless stopcocks and KBr windows. The samples were then reduced in-situ in a hydrogen flow (60 ml/min) for 1 h at 623 K. After reduction the catalysts were outgassed in dynamic vacuum for 0.5 h at the same temperature. In all cases, the samples were cooled to room temperature before exposure to 30 Torr NO (1 Torr = 133.3 Pa). The IR spectra of chemisorbed nitric oxide were recorded on a Nicolet 5 ZDX spectrophotometer at a resolution of 4 cm-~ and were averaged over 100 scans. All spectra were obtained by substraction of a background spectrum recorded before nitric oxide exposure. Adsorption of pyridine was performed on oxidic samples using the same IR ceil. In this case, samples were outgassed at 623 K for 0.5 h and cooled to ambient temperature prior to contact with ca. 2 Torr of pyridine. Physically adsorbed pyridine was removed by outgassing at 393 K for 1 h. 2.3. X-ray measurements X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a Fisons ESCALAB MklI 200R electron spectrometer with a Mg and X-ray source (MgKe~ = 1253.6 62 S. Damyanova, J.L. G. Fierro / Applied Catalysis A." General 144 (1996) 59-77 eV) and an hemispherical electron analyser. The powder samples were first pressed inside aluminium cylinders and mounted on a sample rod placed in the pre-treatment chamber of the spectrometer. Calcined samples were outgassed in the pre-treatment chamber at ambient temperature for 1 h before transferring to the analysis chamber. In-situ pre-treatments in hydrogen were carried out at 623 K. The ion-pumped analysis chamber was maintained below 3.10-9 TO1T during data acquisition. All binding energies (BE) were referenced to the C ls line at 284.5 eV giving BE values within an accuracy of + 0.2 eV. 2.4. Catalytic activity The hydroconversion of thiophene was carried out over 0.1 g of catalyst in a micro flow reactor under atmospheric pressure, a reaction temperature of 623 K and WHSV of 2 h-l. Prior to thiophene admission the catalysts were heated to reaction temperature in-situ in a flow of hydrogen (40 ml/min) for 1 h. Hydrogen and thiophene were then passed through the reactor, with reaction products analysed by a gas chromatography. The concentration of thiophene in the hydrogen-thiophene reactant mixture was 6 vol.-%. The hydrogen sulphide released during thiophene hydrogenolysis is revealed as sulphiding agent. The catalytic behaviour of the samples was evaluated on the basis of thiophene conversion to hydrocarbons (~C4) and hydrogen sulphide. The steady-state conversion was achieved after 2 h. 3. Results 3.1. Infrared spectroscopy 3.1.1. Spectra in KBr pellet The IR spectra of titania-supported 12-molybdophosphoric acid and its Co and Ni salts containing higher molybdenum loading and calcined at 623 K are presented in Fig. 1. For comparison the IR spectra of bulk 12-molybdophos- phoric acid (HPMo) and its salts (CoPMo, NiPMo), dried at 393 K are also shown. In the spectrum of HPMo (Fig. la) the main bands at 1065, 962, 875 and 790 cm-1 correspond to Vas(P--Od), Vas(MO-Ot), Vas(MO-Ob-MO) and vas(Mo- Oc-Mo) vibrations, respectively, characterizing PMo120430- anion with Keggin structure [18]. The low value of va~(Mo-O0 (ca. 10 cm-I lower than in H20 solution [19]) for the solid acid (Fig. la) could be due to the loss of crystalliza- tion water, leading to anhydrous heteropolyoxo compound. The substitution of H+ by Co2+ ions results in some shift in the frequencies of most of the bands to lower frequencies for CoPMo sample (from 1060 to 1045 cm-~ and from 962 to 955 cm ~) but the spectrum of NiPMo remains unchanged compared to that of HPMo (Fig. la,b,c). Fierro / Applied Catalysis A: General 144 (1996) 59-77 It is seen from the spectra, that there is a perturbation of the heteropolyanion symmetry, most probably due to a loss of water molecules and/or to anion-ca- tion and supported species-support interactions. Such decreasing of frequencies has already been interpreted by the weakening of anion-anion interactions and the increasing of anion-cation interaction [18]. Following Rocchiccioli-De- ltcheff et al. [18] the band at about 1060 cm-1 has been attributed to the triply degenerated asymmetric stretching vibration of the central PO4 tetrahedron. The appearance of a shifting of this band implies a lowering of the symmetry from Td to C2v. This band is rather broad for NiPMo sample (Fig. 1). The substitu- tion of H+ by Co2+ ions results in weakening the P-O bond and in lowering the frequency of the 1060 cm- ~ band. The 960 cm- ~ band has been assigned to stretching vibration involving central Mo atom and isolated terminal oxygen (Mo-Ot) on the periphery of each of the twelve MoO6 coordination octahedra which complete the Keggin unit on the basis of the shorter length of this bond [ 18]. In agreement with data of Rochiccioli-Deltcheff et al. [ 18,19] and Misono [2] the shift of v(M-Ot) to lower frequency correlates with intermolecular interactions such as H bonds between external oxygens and water molecules, i.e., it is due to a loss of hydrogen bonding between Ot and water. Other authors [22] have concluded that the loss of 'water of constitution' is observed after outgassing at 573 K of HPA by the disappearance of the IR band at 3250 cm- 1. According to the observations in Refs. [21,23] the splitting of the bands at 1065 and 960 cm-z for CoPMo sample may correspond to a partial degradation of HPA in solution to a polyanion of the type (PMo~ ~O39)~-. Since the splitting is not very large, a formation of Co complex with this anion would be supposed [1]. The spectra shown on Fig. 1 demonstrate that a deformation of the het- eropolyanion is present as a result from the influence of the countercation, heat treatment and support effect. The present observation in the IR spectra may be interpreted as transformed species that are a dehydrated form of the supported heteropolyanions, which is the defect Keggin structure [19]. Although titania is known as a support which interacts strongly with supported species, in this case the thermal stability of HPMo and its salts clearly increases after supporting them on titania. 3.1.2. Pyridine adsorption The spectra of the samples recorded after adsorption of pyridine at room temperature and outgassing at 393 K are shown in Fig. 2. It is interesting to note that all the spectra show a similarity in the region 1400-1600 cm-j. The observed bands are recorded always in the same positions (Table 1), but with different relative intensities due to electron density changes in the pyridine molecule through bonding to the surface acid sites. The bands at 1585, 1485 and 1448 cm-~ correspond to coordinated pyridine molecules and characterize Lewis acid sites [24]. Parent titania exhibits only surface Lewis acid sites at S. More specifically, Cook [25] has assigned it to an in-plane skeletal deformation mode (v19b) which induces N-H grouping. Hence, the suppression of this band together with simultaneous appearing of the bands at 1485 and 1585 cm l, according to Ref. [26], would be expected as a result from the distortion of the crystal structure. As all these bands are recorded in all cases, both BrCnsted and Lewis surface acid sites exist in all catalysts. In order to quantify the differences in acidity of the samples, the ratio of BrCnsted to Lewis acidity (B/L) was calculated from the ratio of integrated band intensities at ca. 1540 and ca. 1448 cm-~ and the values corresponding to the ratio are presented in Table 1. The stronger 1448 cm- ~ band for CoPMo/T samples induces a decrease in the B/L ratio, especially in the case of CotPMo/T sample (Fig. 2, Table 1), which value is only 0.25 significantly lower than the value found for other samples. Hence, the decreasing of the values of the B/L ratio is due to both an increase in the concentration of Lewis surface acid sites and a decrease in Br0nsted acid sites (Fig. 2). On the basis of the finding of Furuta et al. [27] it has been concluded that the acidic sites of HPMo acid and its salts are essentially of BrCnsted (protonic) type and the protons that exist on the surface of the HPMo unit together with one or two water molecules (H+(H20) or H+(H20)e) are the origin of the acidity. 66 S. Damyanova, J.L.G. Fierro / Applied Catalysis A: General 144 (1996) 59-77 According to these authors the Lewis acid sites, expressed by pyridine coordi- nated with metal ion, are very few or absent for the acid. However, our results show that supported HPMo acid possesses Lewis acidity which increases significantly after incorporation of Co and Ni due to the basic character of these dopant. According to Martin et al. [28] the bands at 1585 and 1448 cm-J would be associated with coordinatively unsaturated cations (Co2+ and Ni2+) and Mon+ species, respectively. The decrease in Br0nsted acidity of HzPMo/T sample, predominant in H1PMo/T (Fig. 2 and Table 1) may be related to a better dispersion of molybdate species at low loading, due to a strong interaction between the titania support and the Keggin unit by means of the OH surface groups and the acidic protons [29]. On the other hand, a loss of protons by reaction with oxygen of the Keggin unit [15,30] during vacuum pre-treatment of the samples would be the result. In fact, the intensity of the 1540 cm-t band for HPMo/T samples associated with BrCnsted acidity is not very high compared to other samples independently of the highest values of B/L ratio for the former. The detection of BrOnsted acidity for supported Ni and Co salts of HPMo is not surprising although it has been shown [31,32] that substitution of H+ by Na+ leads to a decreasing of Br0nsted acidity. According to our results and literature data this could explain the enhanced BrCnsted acidity in the samples. Moffat [15,26], studying the acidity of the salts of 12-tungstophosphoric and 12-molybdophosphoric acid, has found that the Br0nsted acid sites resulted from the incomplete stoichiometry of the salts and that the divalent 12-heteropoly salts are a mixture of the parent acid and a divalent cation salt. The relative high Brcnsted acidity for CoPMo/T and NiPMo/T can be attributed to some hydrolysis of the 12-molybdophosphate anion, [PMo 12040]3-, producing hydro- gen ions [1,4,29] during preparation of the salts: PMol203o + 3H20 ~ PMo~O~9 + MoO~- + 6H+ That agrees with the results obtained from the IR spectra for CoPMo sample. The absence of band splitting and shifting at 960 cm- J for NiPMo sample (Fig. 1) does not mean that hydrolysis did not occur for this sample. The hydrolytic degradation of the salts of [PMo1204o]3- anion has been attributed by Tsigdinos [14] to the fact that 12-molybdophosphoric acid possesses 'reserved' acidities higher than 3. As it is seen from Fig. 2 and Table 1, the Br0nsted acidity of NiPMo/T samples is practically the same as that of HPMo/T samples. According to results observed by other workers [33,34] the electronegativity of the counterca- tion affects the acid strength of the samples. The electronegativity of Co cations is higher compared to Ni2+ ones [35] and hence a dissociation of evolved water may be observed more on highly reducible Ni, on the one hand. The protons produced by dissociation of water on the metal cations react with some oxygen atoms of phosphoromolybdate anion [30], on the other hand. S. Damyano~'a, J.L.G. Nitric oxide adsorption Adsorption of NO on reduced titania-supported catalysts gives bands at 1807-1810 and 1702-1706 cm-~ that may be assigned to symmetric and antisymmetric NO stretching, respectively, of paired nitric oxide molecules held as dinitrosyls adsorbed on partially reduced molybdenum sites [36,37]. The bands have been previously shown to arise from NO adsorbed on molybdenum ions with valence state lower than 5 [37]. The reduction of the samples leads to a significant increase in the intensities of both NO bands on the one hand and to red shift of the frequencies by about 5-10 cm-1 as compared to calcined samples [38] on the other (Fig. 3 and Table 2). This shift has been interpreted as indicative of an increase in the degree of unsaturation [37]. Three bands are observed for CoPMo/T samples after reduction: 1890-1896, 1812-1819 and 1712-1715 cm-~ (Fig. 3(A,B)). Obviously, the intensity of the band at 1812-1819 cm ~ is dominated by the contribution of cobalt since the contribution of Mo as shown by the 1711-1715 cm-1 band is rather weak. The main effect of reduction is that the number of cobalt sites, able to adsorb NO, on the surface increases. The fact that the antisymmetric stretching band is shifted of about 10-12 cm 1 in both, reduced unpromoted and Co promoted catalysts (from 1702-1706 cm-~ in HPMo/T to 1712-1715 cm 1 in CoPMo/T), can be taken as indirect evidence of an interaction between Co and Mo ions. Similar shifts have been found by TopsCe and TopsCe [40] on reduced CoMo/A1203 and Artega et al. [41] on unpromoted and Co promoted sulphided catalysts. The highest frequency band at 1873 cm- ~ in the spectra of the samples with high Mo, NiIPMo/T, (Fig. 3(A-b)) is arisen from NO adsorbed on Ni2+ sites [42]. A lighter reduction of Ni2+ to Niis observed for the sample with lower Ni loading, Ni2PMo/T, (Fig. 3(B-b)). The revealed 1856 cm-~ band with shoulder at 1877 cm ~ shows that upon reduction a complete replacement of oxygen atoms coordinated to the surface Ni atoms by protons occurs [37] (Fig. 3(B-b)). Variation in the relative intensities of the bands due to symmetric/antisym- metric stretching vibration of adsorbed nitric oxide (listed in Table 2), indicating a change in dipole angle (0), have been considered to show the differences in the morphology of ionic Mo sites [36,37]. Both HPMo/T samples show nitric oxide adsorbed in a form with the same dipole angle of 110.3(Table 2). Thiophene HDS activity data The thiophene conversion of the catalysts decreases with time and reaches an apparent steady-state activity after approximately 90-120 rain. It should be noted that the conversion increases with Mo loading for HPMo/T and CoPMo/T catalysts. The effect of Mo loading on thiophene conversion can be better illustrated by determination of the specific activity (activity expressed per gram of Mo) as shown in Table 2. The highest activity is obtained for Ni2PMo/T catalyst having lower molybdenum loading. Increasing the Mo loading for CoPMo/T and HPMo/T catalysts leads to a pronounced decrease in the specific activity. 4. Discussion The results of pyridine adsorption experiment lead to the conclusion that there is some relationship between the dispersion of supported compounds and their acidity. The appearance of high concentration of Br0nsted acid sites at high loading of the deposited molybdenum species (Fig. 2, Table 1) is associated with the increase in the surface density of the molecularly dispersed surface species. The increased initial thiophene conversion would be caused by en- hanced proton acidity of the catalysts. The HPMo/T samples showed the highest initial thiophene conversion, but their deactivation is faster compared to that of Co and Ni modified samples. In spite of this strong deactivation of the catalysts the activity is still relatively high for these catalysts after 3-4 h reaction. The combined use of IR and XPS techniques gives information about the structure and dispersion of the heteropoly compounds on the support. The change in the values of XPS IMo/lzi ratios with Mo loading would be attributed to the changes in the surface coverage. Since MoO3 is not detected in the IR spectra of the calcined samples, it is clear that the thermal stability of the phosphoromolybdates is enhanced as a result of their interaction with some sites of titania surface that stabilize them. The increase in the resolution of the Mo 3d doublet for CoPMo/T samples (Fig. 5(A)) suggests a decrease in the extent of the interaction between the supported molybdenum species and the support, indicative of well dispersed polymerized Mo6+. NO adsorption and XPS measurements of only evacuated catalysts show that molybdenum is partly reduced. Most probably, when the temperature is risen, water is formed from oxygen atoms of anion and protons [30], producing coordinatively unsaturated Mo ions. High extent of reduction of the catalysts leads to a drop in the dispersion of supported phosphoromolybdate anions. This is also confirmed by comparison of the XPS IMo/ITi ratios in oxidic and reduced samples (Fig. 6, Table 3). The S. Damyanova, J.L.G. Fierro /Applied Catalysis A: General 144 (1996) 59- 77 75 equivalent ratios for HPMo/T may be due to the stabilization effect of the titania support that permits more homogeneous adsorption of polyanion from acidic solution and interaction with hydrated titanium ions. The decrease in XPS IMo/IT~ for CoPMo/T and NiPMo/T samples could be due to some segrega- tion of Mo sites or their diffusion into the support. The higher values of XPS lco/I~o ratios show that a substantial part of Co2+ ions is located on the Mo atoms following reduction. The fact that the intensity of NO adsorbed on Co2+ ions in reduced CoPMo/T catalysts is about twice times higher than that in unreduced ones [38], indicates that in the former case the Co atoms are exposed in a high extent. NO adsorption on reduced CoPMo/T samples showed some reduction of molybdenum independently of the XPS results, which does not show reduced Mo, especially for the Co~PMo/T sample. The sensitivity limitation of XPS is concerned not to allow the detection of a few percent of reduced molybdenum ions on the presence of majority of Mo in a higher oxidation state (Mo6+ and/or Mo5 +). The proposed formation of the Co complex with the phosphoromolybdate anion during catalyst preparation does not permit lighter reduction of molybde- num but these catalysts with higher concentration of exposed unreduced Co sites may exhibit high activity in thiophene HDS (Table 2). The thiophene adsorption sites would be at incomplete reduced Mo ions with an interaction through Co2+ ions. In view of the catalytic importance of the location of Co atoms the synergetic effect of Co has been shown in supported and unsupported CoMo sulphide systems [50-55]. In the intercalation model proposed by De Beer et al. [50] the authors have assumed the migration of Co from the bulk to the small crystalline MoS2 where Co2+ is intercalated. According to the model proposed by TopsCe et al. [51] the observed contact between Co and Mo is likely a precursor of the so-called 'CoMoS' phase, which is responsible for the synergy between Co and Mo during sulphidation of the catalysts. According to Ledoux et al. [52], the role of Co in sulphided CoMo catalysts is to increase the fraction of Mo edge atoms. Delmon [53] suggested that hydrogenation and hydrodesul- phurization sites are the reduced molybdenum centers. We have no direct arguments for the existence of these kinds of species during thiophene hy- drogenolysis, but the similarities between our data and literature data support that the active sites are not fully reduced (or sulfided) under our relatively mild reaction conditions. On the basis of our results the role of Co would consist in: (i) Co inhibits the segregation of Mo in oxidic samples; (ii) some interaction between Co and adjacent Mo stabilizes the phosphoromolybdate anion on the surface that could be related to synergetic effect of Co during HDS reaction. The reduction of Mo is more pronounced in Ni-promoted catalysts. XPS and NO adsorption show that firstly molybdenum atoms are reduced and this process is enhanced by the presence of Ni. Metallic nickel in vicinity would be a source of hydrogen atoms for the reduction of Mo6+, as well as for Ni2+ ions. As the Ni content increases the extent of Mo reduction is higher (Table 2 and Fig. 4). 76 S. Damyanoca, J.L.G. This is an indication of enhanced dispersion of Mo species in NizPMo/T in comparison with Co2PMo/T. The latter may cause the highest activity of NizPMo/T sample (Table 2). This unambiguously shows that the promotion effect of Ni is revealed by the enhanced dispersion of Mo sites and their lighter reduction at lower concentration of the components. coredata.dc:description: Titania-supported 12-molybdophosphoric acid and its Co(Ni) salts were studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and Fourier transform IR spectroscopy in the mid-infrared range and of adsorbed nitric oxide and pyridine. Hydrodesulphurization of thiophene was used as test reaction of the samples. The results provide additional support for the preservation of phosphoromolybdate anion on titania-support after its supporting. The highest activity of nickel promoted catalysts may be caused by an increase in dispersion of molybdenum and its lighter reduction.
coredata.dc:title: Surface properties of titania-supported 12-molybdophosphoric acid hydrodesulphurization catalysts
